abstract.text: A container view controller that manages a tab view interface, which organizes multiple pages of content but displays only one page at a time.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Each page of content is managed by a separate child view controller. Navigation between child view controllers is accomplished with the help of an

object, which the tab view controller manages. When the user selects a new tab, the tab view controller displays the content associated with the associated child view controller, replacing the previous content.
Each tab is represented by an

object, which contains the name of the tab and stores a pointer to the child view controller that manages the tab’s content. Normally, you configure the tab view items at design time using Interface Builder, but you can also add them programmatically using the methods of this class. Always assign a child view controller to new tab view items before adding those items to the tab view interface.
Another way to add tabs programmatically is to add child view controllers directly to the tab view controller. When you call the
method of this class, the tab view controller automatically creates a default
object for the specified view controller. You can fetch the newly created item using the
method and configure it. Removing a child view controller with the
method similarly removes the corresponding tab view item.

The tab view controller lazily loads the views associated with each child view controller, creating them only after the corresponding tab is selected. When the tab view controller’s view is first displayed, only the view for the initially selected tab is loaded.

property determines the appearance of the tab controls. A tab view controller can display a segmented control or display tabs in the window’s toolbar. You can also provide your own control for displaying tabs. The tab view controller automatically coordinates interactions between designated control and the corresponding

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A set of methods that support the mediation of a custom segue.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A multipage interface that displays one page at a time.
A container view controller that manages a tab view interface, which organizes multiple pages of content but displays only one page at a time.
Tab control style options for a tab view controller.
Adds the specified tab to the end of the tab view controller’s list of tabs.
A Boolean value indicating whether the tab view controller gets its title from the selected child view controller.
Inserts a tab view into the tab view controller’s list of tabs.
Removes the specified tab view item from the tab view controller.
The index of the selected tab.
The style used to display the tabs.
The tab view that manages the views of the interface.
Informs the tab view controller that the specified tab was selected.
Asks the tab view controller if the specified tab should be selected.
Informs the tab view controller that the specified tab is about to be selected.
Returns the tab view item for the specified child view controller.
The array of tab view items used to manage each of the child view controllers.
Returns the toolbar item for the specified identifier.
Returns the array of identifier strings for the allowed toolbar items.
Returns the array of identifier strings for the default toolbar items.
Returns the array of identifier strings for the selectable toolbar items
The animation options to use when switching between tabs.
Called after the view controller’s view has been loaded into memory.
The
protocol defines the optional methods implemented by delegates of
objects.
An item in a tab view.
A set of optional methods you use to configure the toolbar and respond to changes.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
A controller that manages a view, typically loaded from a nib file.
A convenience method for adding a child view controller at the end of the
array.
An array of view controllers that are hierarchical children of the view controller.
Inserts a specified child view controller into the
array at a specified position.
Removes a specified child controller from the view controller.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
